headline.main: Today in Small Business: $100 Billion in Lending

docs.abstract: The case for having a human-resources office. Affordable Care Act enrollees are leaving jobs and starting businesses. And what’s the fastest-growing alcoholic beverage category?

headline.main: Can You Afford Your Medicine? Doctors Don't Ask

docs.abstract: Neither doctors nor medical students can solve a patient’s financial problems on the spot. Yet any one of us can be the first to detect a problem.

docs.lead_paragraph: India said on Thursday it would hold trade talks on intellectual property rights with the United States after its general election, buying time to address friction over drug patents until a new government is formed.

headline.main: India Invites U.S. to Discuss IP, Market Access Issues

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans are relishing the chance to use confirmation hearings for Sylvia Mathews Burwell, President Barack Obama's nominee as U.S. health secretary, to re-energize their election-year attacks on his signature healthcare initiative.

headline.main: Republicans to Push Anti-Obamacare Message in Senate Hearings
headline.print_headline: Republicans to Push Anti-Obamacare Message in Senate Hearings

docs.lead_paragraph: A report from S&P Capital IQ projects that by 2020, about 90 percent of American workers who now receive health insurance through their employers will be shifted to government exchanges.
docs.snippet: A report from S&P Capital IQ projects that by 2020, about 90 percent of American workers who now receive health insurance through their employers will be shifted to government exchanges.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study finds the new health care law could create big savings for companies.

headline.main: Envisioning the End of Employer-Provided Health Plans
headline.print_headline: Implications for Employers in New Health Care Law

docs.abstract: The Upshot; study conducted by S&P Capital IQ finds that the new health care law could create big savings for companies; says practice of buying health insurance through government exchanges could save biggest American companies $700 billion between 2016 and 2025, and total could reach $3.25 trillion for all companies with more than 50 employees.
docs.snippet: A new study finds the new health care law could create big savings for companies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite improved living standards, the poor have fallen further behind the middle class and the affluent in both consumption and income, and crucial services remain unattainable.

headline.main: Changed Life of the Poor: Better Off, but Far Behind
headline.print_headline: Changed Life of the Poor: Better Off, but Far Behind

docs.abstract: Economists say while electronics and other factory-made goods are now within reach of poor Americans, crucial services like education, health care and child care remain unattainable; hold that federal programs and falling prices account for much of the change in poor families' consumption over the past generation; starkly different views on poverty and inequality emerge again as Senate Republicans filibuster proposal to raise national minimum wage.
docs.snippet: Despite improved living standards, the poor have fallen further behind the middle class and the affluent in both consumption and income, and crucial services remain unattainable.

docs.lead_paragraph: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce said Wednesday that only two-thirds of people signing up for private health insurance in the federal exchange had paid by April 15.

headline.main: Not All Health Care Premiums Are Paid Up, House Panel Says
headline.print_headline: Not All Health Care Premiums Are Paid Up, House Panel Says

docs.abstract: House Committee on Energy and Commerce says only two-thirds of people who signed up for private health insurance in federal exchange paid their premiums by April 15; without payment, consumers will not have coverage; Obama administration questions data, which Republican Rep Fred Upton, chairman of committee, says provides true picture of national enrollment in the exchange as of mid-April.
docs.snippet: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce said Wednesday that only two-thirds of people signing up for private health insurance in the federal exchange had paid by April 15.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act makes screening tests like mammograms free. But if you have a breast lump and need a diagnosis, you have to pay.

headline.main: The Problem With Free Health Care
headline.print_headline: The Problem With Free Health Care

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof H Gilbert Welch maintains there is significant room for improvement in the Affordable Care Act, especially in the way it favors screening over diagnosis; holds current system could discourage a woman with a breast lump from reporting symptoms for fear of having to pay diagnostic fees; calls for elimination of fee mismatch between two types of service.
docs.snippet: The Affordable Care Act makes screening tests like mammograms free. But if you have a breast lump and need a diagnosis, you have to pay.
